Award.AwardTitle: GEM Student Support Workshops for Historically Black Colleges and Universities

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
The Historically Black Colleges and Universities - Undergraduate Program (HBCU-UP) supports conferences and workshops that seek to increase the representation of science, technology, engineering, and mathematics (STEM) students at HBCUs in graduate school and the workforce. In that regard, the National GEM Consortium will conduct a workshop on the campus of six HBCU campuses for undergraduate STEM students to enable them to compete for competitive graduate fellowships such as the National Science Foundation Graduate Fellowship Program; position them for acceptance to graduate school; and establish peer networks on each campus. The workshop will model the successful GEM GRAD Labs and integrate strategies designed to reduce attrition and increase students' time to degree by focusing on financial options such as fellowships, internships, and research assistantships.

The workshop will adopt a format that has been used successfully in outreach programs designed to broaden the participation of underrepresented minorities in STEM. The format is portable and designed to optimize the participation of students on the six targeted campuses. The workshop expects to impact about 600 undergraduate STEM students who will be better positioned to pursue graduate programs and careers. The format could be replicated at other institutions and provide the impetus for sustaining this activity as an infrastructure enhancement.

POR.DRECONTENT:
A GEM GRAD Lab is a one-day series of workshops that are designed for underrepresented undergraduate STEM majors. GRAD Labs are designed to educate attendees about the importance of pursuing a graduate degree and also how to finance a graduate education. They are conducted by academia and industry subject matter experts, covering topics such as (i) The importance of pursuing a graduate education, (ii) Financing a graduate education, and (iii) Testimonials from former participants.

The goals of this project are to expand the GEM GRAD Lab portfolio by adding six new Historically Black College and University (HBCU) focused GRAD Labs in order to increase the number of underrepresented applying to and enrolling in graduate degree program.

This project served eight HBCU focused GRAD Labs. In total more than 500 students attending HBUCs were served by the related activities.

Project goals were met as participants noted the positive impact attendance had on their goals to attend graduate school. They also indicated a greater understanding of the financial resources that were available to help them attain their graduate degree. More specifically, significant results include an increased number of HBCU GRAD Lab attendees who expressed an interest in going to graduate school. Program attendees reported that the program had a direct impact on their career plans with participants indicating that they had changed their plans and were definitely going to graduate school. Others indicated that while they were already thinking about going to graduate school and getting a Master’s degree, attending the program made them want to pursue a PhD. Finally, some participants noted that the experience confirmed their desire to attend graduate school.
